headline.main: The Enduring Appeal of the Something-Free Diet

docs.abstract: Whether it’s fat, sugar or gluten, cutting something out of our diet appeals to us like nothing else, ANNA NORTH writes. Why do narratives of getting rid of something have such staying power?
docs.snippet: Whether it’s fat, sugar or gluten, cutting something out of our diet appeals to us like nothing else, ANNA NORTH writes. Why do narratives of getting rid of something have such staying power?

docs.lead_paragraph: The drugs don't work - and neither does the market, when it comes to antibiotics.

headline.main: How to Fix a Broken Market in Antibiotics

docs.lead_paragraph: Do donkeys get depressed? Are some aoudads anxious? And what can a zoo’s shrink do to help ease their minds?
docs.abstract: Alex Halberstadt article examines changing attitudes in scientific community toward idea that animals think and feel; highlights work of animal behaviorist Dr Vint Virga, whose book The Soul of All Living Creatures embraces such notions; explores implications of idea on issues of zoos and animal rights.
docs.snippet: Do donkeys get depressed? Are some aoudads anxious? And what can a zoo’s shrink do to help ease their minds?

docs.lead_paragraph: HUTTER--Dr. Robert V.P., a renowned pathologist died July 2, surrounded by his wife and children in New Jersey, at 85, after years with Alzheimer's disease. A past president of the American Cancer Society, former chairman of the department of pathology at St. Barnabas Medical Center, former editor-in-chief of the journal Cancer, he shaped cancer prevention strategies nationally and internationally. At the ACS, he helped to launch the society's first nutrition guidelines. He was the rare pathologist sought out by cancer patients for advice and what they got in return was a compassionate expert with sensitivity and honesty. Born May 25th, 1929 in Yonkers, NY, he attended Syracuse University on scholarship, played football for Coach F. Ben Schwartzwalder, graduated from SUNY Health Science Center at Syracuse, did his residency at Yale University and at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, served two years of active duty in the Navy, returned to Memorial, then to Yale and became a tenured professor of pathology at the age of 39. In 1970, he served for three years as chairman of pathology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and subsequently moved to St. Barnabas. He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Lauterbach, son Andrew (Barbara), daughters Randi (Stuart) and Edie, and ten grandchildren.

docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron called on Wednesday for global action to tackle the threat of drug-resistant superbugs and said Britain planned to take a leading role in finding ways to spur the development of new antibiotics.
